bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to Blanton P. Seward, January 2, 1931

div1.p: [Carter] answers Seward's questions about Henry Rose Carter and provides information about obtaining a photograph of Carter.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Blanton P. Seward, January 2, 1931
div1.opener:
Richmond Apartments,
2030 Highland Avenue,
Birmingham, Alabama.
January 2, 1931.
Dr. Blanton P. Seward,
Lewis-Gale Hospital,
Roanoke, Virginia.
Dear Doctor Seward:
div1.p:
Your letter of December 22nd. would have been answered
earlier had it not been for some page proof, which had to be got-
ten off before Xmas. Thank you very much for the return of Dr.
Frost's unpublished notes on my Father, also for the enclosed
stamps--a rare piece of thoughtfulness, which I seldom encounter
when furnishing information, as I am often compelled to do, by
registered mail.

1: Father's first campaign for the control of malaria inthe U. S.
(conducted with conspicuous success) was in 1913, at Roanoke Rapids,
North Carolina.

2: Dr. Joseph H. White, who assisted Father in yellow fever epi-
demics and, in 1905, eliminated yellow fever in New Orleans in a
brilliant campaign, is from Georgia. He also, from about 1921, did
yellow fever work for the Rockefeller Foundation, being in charge of
their work in Brazil for many years. He is an officer in the U. S.
Public Health Service (retired).

3; Dr. Frost is a Virginian and was considered by my Father the
foremost epidemiologist of America. Certainly he is one of the fore-
most of his time. He is, as you probably know, Dean of the Johsns
Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, 615 North Wolfe St.,
Baltimore, Md.

I take it for granted that you know that our Surgeon General, Dr.
Hugh S. Cumming, of the U. S. Public Health Service is a Virginian.

I am enclosing my copy of The Bulletin of the International Health
Board for October 1925, which contains a photograph of Father as, I
regret to say, I have no others, save framed ones, available, If this
cannot be reproduced for your paper, you can get an unmounted copy
from the photographer on “shiney paper” (a “squegee” as they are called)
for from 50 cts. to a dollar. These reproduce[unclear] far better than the
dull finish used in regular photographs. The photographer is

“Madame Jeanne Bennett,
5 East Hamilton Street,
Baltimore, Md.”

Tell her that you want “the official photograph” of Dr. Carter. It is
so called as being the one most used. By the way, this photograph is
the basis of a portrait, painted after Father's death, which was hung
in Hanover Court House, with those of Patrick Henry, Henry Clay and
other “sons of Hanover” in 1926. The Inscription “Lux exstincta lucet”
lucet”
was chosen by Dr. Thayer, of Baltimore, and the rest of the in-
scription by the late Dr. Ennion Willioms, of Virginia.

I wish much that I could see you and show you whatever I
have that might be of use to you. I am impressed with the thorough
way in which you are going about your paper, taking time to really
collect your data, and feel sure that the result will be well worth
the reading. If you ever pass through Birmingham, my brother, his
wife and myself, will bevery glad to see you. My brother, as you
probably know, is a doctor, who is putting into his chosen branceh of
internal medicine the same genius, selfless enthusiasm and indefatiguable
work that Father put into preventive medicine. His wife is a roentgenolo-
gist (M. D. of Tulane) with much post graduate work in her specialty (Massa-
chusetts General, Cornell Clinic etc.) You see then that I am spending
my winter in a familiar and congenial atmosphere.

With very best wishes for the New Year, and trusting that you
will not hesitate to let me know if there is a chance that I may be of
further use to you,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Enclosure,
P. S. There is no hurry about the return of the enclosed Bulletin, al-
though, of course, I would like to have it as soon as convenient to you.
This, because, as you see, it is the only copy I have in my files.
